opennlp.ccg.alignment
Class Alignment

java.lang.Object
  java.util.AbstractCollection<E>
      java.util.AbstractSet<Mapping>
          opennlp.ccg.alignment.Alignment
All Implemented Interfaces:
Comparable<Alignment>, Iterable<Mapping>, Collection<Mapping>, Set<Mapping>
public class Alignment
extends AbstractSet<Mapping>
implements Comparable<Alignment>

An alignment consisting of a pair of phrases and a set of mappings between them.

This class is a flat representation of the mappings between indices in its A-position phrase and its B-position phrase in that it is simply a set of mappings. More granularity is available by calling getTargets(Integer, PhrasePosition), which returns all the indices a certain index is mapped to from a specified position. Alignments also allow their indices to be accessed when the phrase position is not necessarily known, via get(PhrasePosition), getIndices(PhrasePosition), and asMap(PhrasePosition).

A detached view of this alignment as a map whose keys are the indices in a specified position and whose values are the sets of indices that index maps to can be obtained by calling asMap(PhrasePosition). If only the set of indices mapped to by a certain index is required, getTargets(Integer, PhrasePosition) provides similar functionality. The static method fromMap(Phrase, Phrase, Map) allows an alignment to be reconstructed from a map of indices to sets of indices.

A version of this alignment with the phrase positions reversed and all the mappings reversed can be obtained by calling reverse().

Author:
Scott Martin
See Also:
PhrasePosition, Phrase, Mapping

Constructor Detail

Alignment

public Alignment(Phrase a,
                 Phrase b,
                 Collection<? extends Mapping> mappings)
Creates a new alignment with the specified phrases and mappings between them. The specified set of mappings is copied in a way that preserves whatever ordering is present in the original set, via LinkedHashSet.

Parameters:
a - The phrase to use for the "A" position.
b - The phrase to use for the "B" position.
mappings - The mappings between a and b, where the first index is understood to belong to a and the second index is understood to belong to b.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - If either phrase is null, or if phrases a and b do not have matching numbers, if mappings is null, or if any of the mappings have a non-null phrase number that is not equal to the phrases' numbers.
IndexOutOfBoundsException - If any of the mappings contains an index that does not exist in the phrase in the corresponding position.
See Also:
LinkedHashSet

fromMap

public static Alignment fromMap(Phrase a,
                                Phrase b,
                                Map<Integer,Set<Integer>> map)
Creates a new alignment based on the specified phrases and map view of their mappings.

Parameters:
a - The A-position phrase.
b - The B-position phrase.
map - A map whose keys are the A-position indices and whose values are the B-position indices that the corresponding key is mapped to.
Returns:
A new alignment with mappings created based on the specified map.
See Also:
asMap()

reverse

public Alignment reverse()
Creates an alignment based on this one except that the phrases have switched positions and all of the mappings are reversed.

Returns:
A new alignment with the phrases swapped and all the mappings' indices swapped.

getTargets

public Set<Integer> getTargets(Integer source)
Gets the indices mapped to from the specified source, assuming that the source is in the A-position.

Returns:
the value of getTargets(source, PhrasePosition.A)
See Also:
getTargets(Integer, PhrasePosition)

getTargets

public Set<Integer> getTargets(Integer source,
                               PhrasePosition sourcePosition)
Gets the indices mapped to by a specified index starting from the specified position. For example, if an alignment contains the following mappings: 
 7 <-> 4
 3 <-> 4
 4 <-> 4
 ...
Then calling getTargets(4, PhrasePosition.B) returns a set containing 7, 3, and 4.

Calling this method is equivalent to calling asMap(sourcePosition).get(source), with the exception that if no mappings have source in the source position, the empty set is returned rather than null.

Parameters:
source - The index to look for targets of.
sourcePosition - The phrase position to assume the source index belongs to.
Returns:
A set of indices in the opposite position that the specified source index maps to (the same as asMap(sourcePosition).get(source)), or the empty set if no such indices are present.
See Also:
add(Mapping), asMap(PhrasePosition)

getIndices

public Set<Integer> getIndices(PhrasePosition position)
Gets the indices in a specified phrase position. Specifically, returns a set containing every integer i such that there exists a mapping in this alignment that returns i for the call Mapping.get(PhrasePosition) with the specified position as argument.

Parameters:
position - The position to get indices for.
Returns:
The same value as asMap(position).keySet().
See Also:
asMap(PhrasePosition)

asMap

public Map<Integer,Set<Integer>> asMap()
Gets a map view of this alignment from the default phrase position.

See Also:
asMap(PhrasePosition)

asMap

public Map<Integer,Set<Integer>> asMap(PhrasePosition keyPosition)
Gets a map view of this alignment from the specified key position. The returned map's keys are drawn from the mappings by accessing the specified key position, while the values are aggregated together into sets from the indices at keyPosition's opposite position. The returned map contains key/value pairs that can be used to reconstruct the alignment it is based on via the fromMap(Phrase, Phrase, Map) method. That is, calling 
Alignment.fromMap(a.getA(), a.getB(), a.asMap(PhrasePosition.A))
for any alignment a always returns an alignment that is equivalent to a according to the equals(Object) method.

For example, if this alignment contains the following mappings 

 0 <-> 0
 0 <-> 1
 1 <-> 2
 3 <-> 2
then calling asMap(PhrasePosition.A) returns a map with the key/value pairings 
 0=[0, 1]
 1=[2]
 3=[2]
while calling asMap(PhrasePosition.B) gives the map view from the "opposite direction", i.e. 
 0=[0]
 1=[0]
 2=[1, 3]
Note that the order of the keys and values reflects the ordering of the alignment's mappings via LinkedHashMap and LinkedHashSet, and is dependent on its iterator. Also, the behavior of the returned map is not specified if mappings are added are removed to this alignment after a call to asMap().

The returned map is detached from (not backed by) this set of mappings, so keys can be removed from and added to it without any effect on this alignment. Similarly, the sets of indices that are the values of its entry set can be modified without affecting this alignment. The fromMap(Phrase, Phrase, Map) provides the ability to create an alignment based on a map of A indices to sets of B indices.

Parameters:
keyPosition - The phrase position that the resulting maps keys should be taken from.
Returns:
A map whose keys are from the phrase in the specified position, and whose values are sets of indices from the phrase in the opposite position.
See Also:
fromMap(Phrase, Phrase, Map), LinkedHashMap, LinkedHashSet
